April 14, 1991: Fiction
HEARTBEAT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A chance meeting of a man
and a woman, both with successful careers in television, enables them to solve
their marital and romantic problems.
THE DRUID OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) A
new volume in a series about the fantasy land of Shannara.
THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A young lawyer learns that his
firm is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities.
THE EAGLE HAS FLOWN, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) A
German general and an I.R.A. assassin plot a daring rescue attempt.
THE SEERESS OF KELL, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $20.) The fifth
volume in the "Malloreon" fantasy saga.
DAMAGE, by Josephine Hart. (Knopf, $18.) A British gentleman is mesmerized
when he meets the woman his son plans to marry.
COLD FIRE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) A despondent reporter finds
hope and romance while she tracks the course of a good Samaritan.
THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) A couple on
horseback trek across Europe in the Ice Age.
MAGIC HOUR, by Susan Isaacs. (HarperCollins, $21.95.) Murder in the
Hamptons.
CIRCLE OF FRIENDS, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The coming of age
of women in an Irish village and in Dublin's academia.
FORGIVING, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $19.95.) A young woman establishes
a newspaper in Dakota Territory.
FATHER MELANCHOLY'S DAUGHTER, by Gail Godwin. (Morrow, $21.95.) The
plight of a Virginia clergyman's daughter after her mother deserts her father and
her own relationships go awry.
POSSESSION, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $22.95.) A pair of British
academics pursue the relationship between two Victorian poets.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) A woman descended
from witches brings a drowned man back to life.
April 14, 1991
Non-Fiction
YOU'LL NEVER EAT LUNCH IN THIS TOWN AGAIN, by Julia Phillips. (Random
House, $22.) Life in Hollywood as experienced by an Academy Award-winning
producer.
IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male
from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures.
A HISTORY OF THE ARAB PEOPLES, by Albert Hourani. (Belknap/Harvard
University, $24.95.) A comprehensive account from Mohammed's time to the
present; the work of an Oxford scholar.
RIDERS ON THE STORM, by John Densmore. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Memories of
Jim Morrison and the Doors, from the rock band's drummer.
SLEEPWALKING THROUGH HISTORY, by Haynes Johnson. (Norton, $24.95.) A
social history of America during the Reagan era.
AND THE SEA WILL TELL, by Vincent Bugliosi with Bruce B. Henderson. (Norton,
$22.95.) An enigmatic 1974 murder case involving two American couples on a
Pacific atoll.
THE PROMISED LAND, by Nicholas Lemann. (Knopf, $24.95.) The 20th-century
migration of blacks from the rural South to the urban North and the changes it has
wrought.
IN OUR DEFENSE, by Ellen Alderman and Caroline Kennedy. (Morrow, $22.95.)
How the Bill of Rights affects Americans' lives today.
THE PRIZE, by Daniel Yergin. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The role that oil has
played in world history from the mid-19th century to the present.
THE NEXT CENTURY, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $16.95.) A journalist's
assessment of the prospects for various countries, judged by the temperament of
their inhabitants.
YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The
different languages men and women speak and how the sexes can understand
each other better.
MILLIE'S BOOK, as dictated to Barbara Bush. (Morrow, $17.95.) The White House
dog's memoirs.
JIM MORRISON: Dark Star, by Dylan Jones. (Viking Studio, $29.95.) The lead
singer of the Doors recalled through photographs and interviews.
THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf,
$50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures.
